data.title: Why is the star wars main title from episode 7 recorded by a freelance orchestra?
data.meta_description:
Hey, i just rewatched the prequel trilogy and noticed that the main title from episode 7 sounds really weak compared to the prequel recording.
Then i read...
data.text:
Hey, i just rewatched the prequel trilogy and noticed that the main title from episode 7 sounds really weak compared to the prequel recording.

Then i read that it was recorded by an freelance orchestra?

Why didnt they just recorded the theme again with the LSO?

IMO, it would have sounded better if it was recorded by the LSO, because it sounds very weak especially in the intro..

Can somebody explain to me WHY they made this decision, and who came up with that stupid idea??

thanks in advance

Hey, i just rewatched the prequel trilogy and noticed that the main title from episode 7 sounds really weak compared to the prequel recording.

Then i read that it was recorded by an freelance orchestra?

Why didnt they just recorded the theme again with the LSO?

IMO, it would have sounded better if it was recorded by the LSO, because it sounds very weak especially in the intro..

Can somebody explain to me WHY they made this decision, and who came up with that stupid idea??

thanks in advance

I don't know for sure but I believe it's because JW didn't want to/couldn't travel as he was older, so they did the sessions for the sequels in LA

Actually it was Gustavo Dudamel (Chief Conductor of LA Phil) who conducted the main title!

'Star Wars' surprise: Gustavo Dudamel conducted parts of 'The Force Awakens' score

One of the surprise stars in “Star Wars: The Force Awakens” is a musical one: Gustavo Dudamel, music director of the Los Angeles Philharmonic, conducted the opening and end titles music by composer John Williams.

I don't know for sure but I believe it's because JW didn't want to/couldn't travel as he was older, so they did the sessions for the sequels in LA

Actually it was Gustavo Dudamel (Chief Conductor of LA Phil) who conducted the main title!

'Star Wars' surprise: Gustavo Dudamel conducted parts of 'The Force Awakens' score

One of the surprise stars in “Star Wars: The Force Awakens” is a musical one: Gustavo Dudamel, music director of the Los Angeles Philharmonic, conducted the opening and end titles music by composer John Williams.

Hmmm, thank you!

That would explain it, but still the brass section is too quiet in the intro, the trombones/trumpets are suposed to play at least F marcatos and staccs....

Hmmm, thank you!

That would explain it, but still the brass section is too quiet in the intro, the trombones/trumpets are suposed to play at least F marcatos and staccs....

It doesn’t get any better than the top shelf LA studio orchestra that recorded it, though it is true that the heavy brass are disappointingly weak. That said, it’s not their fault; they did as they were told, as they anlways do, and nothing need be said beyond that.

__________

I think with the Rebel Alliance being scattered and spread thin for so many years and the New Republic never able to get their act together, it's probably all they could muster for an orchestra at that point.

And if you think that freelance orchestra was sub-par, wait 'til you see some of the players from Andor...

Edit: In all seriousness, I should add that the Andor soundtrack is brilliant and the funeral march is one of the best tracks of the entire lot! Nicholas Britell did an amazing job.

Hey, i just rewatched the prequel trilogy and noticed that the main title from episode 7 sounds really weak compared to the prequel recording.

Then i read that it was recorded by an freelance orchestra?

Why didnt they just recorded the theme again with the LSO?

IMO, it would have sounded better if it was recorded by the LSO, because it sounds very weak especially in the intro..

Can somebody explain to me WHY they made this decision, and who came up with that stupid idea??

thanks in advance

I'm not fully sure but I think it had to do with the union here in Los Angeles. They've got exclusive rights with certain studios and these studios can only record in LA. The old Star Was Prequels were done with Lucas Films which was more of an indie company but when bought by Disney it became a Studio Film. I think that maybe HZ suffered the same fate when doing Superman but since I'm not in that inner circle, pure speculation on my part.

Both LA and London are badass but London has a bigger studio. The brass isn't weak at all but just not as great as THE LSO in Abbey Road

Don't you hear how terribly weak the brass sounds in the opening bars? Just compare the Trombones to the recording of Episode 3 for example.

Thanks for posting. I hear what you are saying about the trombones. Definitely more staccato, and more bold. But listen to these (Ep7 first, followed by Sith):

Here's the very opening, and yes, Sith does sound a bit bolder. But not by a lot. The Sith trombones are also up in the mix more, but that could be a decision based on the performance.

View attachment sw1.mp3

But listen to the trumpets here:

View attachment sw2.mp3

Doesn't Ep7 sound bigger, fuller and bolder?

And listen again to the end of that phrase:

View attachment sw3.mp3

Both have their stronger points, I think.
